Chad (and John), 

This explanation is correct.  It is possible to get wider networks 
because of the phenomenon Chad described.  Note that in 
addition "splitting" isn't necessarily the only way a node could be 
added either.  You could potentially just add a new chain (i.e. link-
node-link) to the network without disabling or removing anything 
that's already there.
I don't think any version of NEAT does that currently but 
theoretically it can work as well.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> hmmm, I thought the answer to this one was simple, but now that I 
think
> about it.... 
> John, you said that your implementation remembers the gene's 
innovation
> number relating to which connection is severed. So that means that 
if
> the link that was disabled to add a node were to be reenabled, then
> split again, it would be interpreted as the other node that did 
the same
> thing. So in that case, it would inhibit horizontal growth, an 
karl put
> it. But in NEAT as I am understanding it from ken's paper, the link
> could be reenabled, then split again, which would disable it 
again. So
> the pattern of reenabling and splitting could repeat indefinitely 
to
> create a wide topology with a large parallel hidden layer. 
> Did I get it right? 
> chad 
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> >From: blackkm7
> >Sent: 8/19/2004 11:00:00 AM
> >To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: Re: [neat] Re: genotype vs phenotype
> >
> >I'm still new to NEAT, but from my limited understanding, if you 
> >prevent certain kinds of (add node) innovations from repeating, 
then 
> >there are certain types of net topologies that cannot evolve. 
> >Specifically, how might a hidden layer evolve that was larger 
than 
> >the input/sensor layer? Horizontal growth as oposed to vertical?
> >
> >Now that I think of it, I've only seen vertical growth in jNeat. 
> >Does NEAT prevent horizontal "bulge" in topologies? And if so, 
why?
> >
> >Thanks,
> >Karl
> >
> >
